facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 426 of 1958 is an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 30, 1958, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Writ Application No. 732 of 1958.

facts.text: Punjab High Court delivered judgment and order dated July 30, 1958 in Civil Writ Application No. 732 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 30, 1958, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Writ Application No. 732 of 1958.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon he came to this Court and was granted special leave.

facts.text: Appellant was appointed to the Indian Police Service on October 1, 1949, and posted to the State of Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was appointed to the Indian Police Service on October 1., 1949, and posted to the State of Punjab.

facts.text: Appellant held charge as Superintendent of Police in various districts.

anchor.surface_text: He held charge as Superintendent of Police in various districts but was reverted as Assistant Superintendent of Police

facts.text: Appellant was reverted as Assistant Superintendent of Police in August 1957.

anchor.surface_text: but was reverted as Assistant Superintendent of Police in August 1957, and was eventually Posted to Dharamsala

facts.text: Appellant was posted to Dharamsala in March 1958.

anchor.surface_text: in August 1957, and was eventually Posted to Dharamsala in March 1958.

facts.text: In March 1958, appellant was informed that action was proposed against him under r. 5 of the All-India Services (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: In the same month he was informed that it was proposed to take action against him under r. 5 of the All-India Services  Discipline and Appeal  Rules, 1955,

facts.text: Appellant was placed under suspension under r. 7 of the Rules pending disciplinary proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: He was thereafter -placed under suspension under r. 7 of the Rules pending disciplinary proceedings against him,

facts.text: Shri K. L. Bhudiraja was appointed enquiry officer to hold departmental enquiry against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: and Shri K. L. Bhudiraja S. was appointed enquiry officer to hold the departmental enquiry against him.

facts.text: Notice was issued to appellant by the Enquiry Officer in July 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Notice was issued to him by the Enquiry Officer in July 1958.

facts.text: Appellant filed application under Art. 226 before Punjab High Court challenging constitutionality of the Act and legality of the enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: He thereupon immediately made an application under Art. 226 of the Constitution before the Punjab High Court challenging the constitutionality

facts.text: Punjab High Court dismissed the writ application on July 30, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The application was dismissed on July 30, 1958, and his application for a certificate

facts.text: Punjab High Court dismissed appellant's application for certificate to appeal to Supreme Court on July 31, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: and his application for a certificate to appeal to this Court was dismissed next day.

facts.text: President passed Constitution (Removal of Difficulties) Order No. II on January 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, the President passed the Constitution  Removal of Difficulties  Order No. II on January 26, 1950,

facts.text: Order No. II adapted Art. 312 by omitting certain words regarding Council of States resolution.

facts.text: All-India Services Act, 1951 (LXI of 1951) was enacted by provisional Parliament.

anchor.surface_text: It was number within the competence of the provisional Parliament to enact the Act in 1951,

facts.text: All-India Services (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, 1955 were framed under s. 3 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Rules when promulgated in 1955 were bad as they were repugnant to Art. 312

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 11, 1958 by Wanchoo, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. December 11. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appellant raised six points challenging constitutionality of the Act and rules.

issues.text: Was the amendment made by the President in Art. 312 of the Constitution by virtue of his power under Art. 392 by the Constitution Removal of Difficulties Order No. II of 26th January, 1950, in excess of the power conferred on him under Art. 392?

anchor.surface_text: 1 , The amendment made by the President in Art. 312 of the Constitution by virtue of his power under Art. 392 by the Constitution Removal of Difficulties Order No. II of 26th January, 1950, was in excess of the power conferred on him under Art. 392

issues.text: Was it within the competence of the provisional Parliament to enact the All-India Services Act in 1951, as there was no compliance with the condition precedent to such an Act being passed under Art. 312?

anchor.surface_text: It was not within the competence of the provisional Parliament to enact the Act in 1951, as there was no compliance with the condition precedent to such an Act being passed under Art. 312

issues.text: Were the Rules promulgated in 1955 bad as they were repugnant to Art. 312 as the amendment made by the President by the Constitution Removal of Difficulties Order No. II had ceased to have force and Art. 312 stood in 1955 as originally enacted in the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: The Rules when promulgated in 1955 were bad as they were repugnant to Art. 312 as the amendment made by the President by the Constitution Removal of Difficulties Order No. 11 had ceased to have force and Art. 312 stood in 1955 as originally enacted in the Constitution

issues.text: Did Art. 312 lay a mandate on Parliament to make a law regulating the recruitment and conditions of service of all-India services created under that Article and could Parliament delegate this function to the Central Government, making s. 3 of the Act invalid?

anchor.surface_text: Art. 312 laid a mandate on Parliament to make a law regulating the recruitment and conditions of service of all- India services created under that Article and Parliament could not delegate this function to the Central Government, and, therefore, s. 3 of the Act was invalid

issues.text: In any event, was the delegation made by s. 3 of the Act excessive, and therefore should section 3 be struck down?

anchor.surface_text: In any event, the delegation made by s. 3 of the Act was excessive and, therefore, section 3 should be struck down

issues.text: Did the Punjab Government have authority to institute these proceedings under the Rules?

anchor.surface_text: and The Punjab Government has no authority to institute these proceedings under the Rules.

issues.text: What is the constitutionality of the All-India Services Act, LXI of 1951?

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave raises the question of the constitutionality of the All-India Services Act, LXI of 1951 hereinafter called the Act .

arguments.claim: The amendment made by the President in Art. 312 of the Constitution by virtue of his power under Art. 392 by the Constitution Removal of Difficulties Order No. II of 26th January, 1950, was in excess of the power conferred on him under Art. 392.

anchor.surface_text: 1 , The amendment made by the President in Art. 312 of the Constitution by virtue of his power under Art. 392 by the Constitution Removal of Difficulties Order No. II of 26th January, 1950, was in excess of the power conferred on him under Art. 392

court_response_anchor.surface_text: shall be the provisional Parliament and shall exercise all the powers and perform all the duties companyferred by the provisions of this Constitution

arguments.court_reasoning: Art. 392 confers wide power on President to adapt Constitution by modification, addition or omission; Sankari Prasad case emphasizes width of power and does not mandate specific manner of adaptation like substitution.

arguments.claim: It was not within the competence of the provisional Parliament to enact the Act in 1951, as there was no compliance with the condition precedent to such an Act being passed under Art. 312.

arguments.court_reasoning: Valid adaptation under Art. 392 removed the condition precedent of Council of States resolution, empowering provisional Parliament to enact the Act without it.

arguments.claim: The Rules when promulgated in 1955 were bad as they were repugnant to Art. 312 as the amendment made by the President by the Constitution Removal of Difficulties Order No. II had ceased to have force and Art. 312 stood in 1955 as originally enacted in the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The Rules when promulgated in 1955 were bad as they were repugnant to Art. 312 as the amendment made by the President by the Constitution Removal of Difficulties Order No. 11 had ceased to have force and Art. 312 stood in 1955 as originally enacted in the Constitution

arguments.court_reasoning: Rules derive authority from valid Act of 1951; reappearance of omitted words in Art. 312 after order expired does not affect validity of Rules framed under permanent Act.

arguments.claim: Art. 312 laid a mandate on Parliament to make a law regulating the recruitment and conditions of service of all-India services created under that Article and Parliament could not delegate this function to the Central Government, and, therefore, s. 3 of the Act was invalid.

anchor.surface_text: Art. 312 laid a mandate on Parliament to make a law regulating the recruitment and conditions of service of all- India services created under that Article and Parliament could not delegate this function to the Central Government, and, therefore, s. 3 of the Act was invalid

arguments.court_reasoning: Words 'Parliament may by law provide' do not exclude delegation; regulation requires numerous varying rules best handled by executive; well-settled law permits delegation within limits.

arguments.claim: In any event, the delegation made by s. 3 of the Act was excessive and, therefore, section 3 should be struck down.

arguments.court_reasoning: R. 5 contemplates institution by government under which officer serving (Punjab per r. 2(b)); punishment authority (Central for major penalties) enters after enquiry per r. 5(9) and Art. 311(2).

arguments.claim: The President did not exceed power under Art. 392 in omitting words from Art. 312 as power is wide to adapt by modification, addition or omission.

Article 392- provides that the President may, for the purpose of removing any difficulties, particularly in relation to the transition from the provisions of the Government of India Act, 1935, to the provisions of this Constitution,

arguments.claim: Delegation of legislative power to frame rules is competent and permitted under Art. 312.

anchor.surface_text: Re. 4. It is contended that Art. 312 lays down a mandate on Parliament to make the law itself regulating the recruitment and the conditions of service of all-India services, and therefore, it was not open to Parliament to delegate any part of the work relating to such regulation to the Central Government by framing Rules for the purpose.

arguments.claim: S. 3 does not involve excessive delegation as s. 4 provides policy by continuing existing rules deemed made under Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 which is important is in these terms- All rules in force immediately before the commencement of this Act and applicable to an all-India service shall continue to be in force and shall be deemed to be rules made under this Act.

arguments.claim: Punjab Government competent to institute disciplinary proceedings under r. 5 as appellant serving in connection with Punjab affairs.

arguments.claim: Enquiry instituted by serving state government even if major penalty by Central Government post-enquiry.

holdings.text: The power given to the President under Art. 392 was very wide and it cannot be said that he could make the adaptation in one way and not in another. It was left to him to consider whether the adaptation should be by way of modification, addition or omission and if he thought it necessary or expedient with respect to a particular Article that adaptation should be by way of omission it cannot be said that he had exceeded his power.

anchor.surface_text: The power given to the President under Art. 392 was very wide and it-cannot be said that he -could make the adaptation in one way and number in another. It was left to him to companysider whether the adaptation should be by way of modification, addition or omission, as he may deem to be necessary or expedient provided that numbersuch order shall be made after the first meeting of Parliament duly companystituted under Chapter 11 of Part V .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 392 expressly authorizes adaptations by modification, addition or omission to remove difficulties during transition; Sankari Prasad affirms wide power without mandating specific form like substitution.

holdings.text: Once it is held that the adaptation made by the President in Art. 312 was within his power, [...] the provisional Parliament would have power to pass the Act without any resolution being passed before the law was made.

anchor.surface_text: Once it is held that the adaptation made by the President in Art. 312 was within his power, there is very little left in the other two points raised by Mr. Chatterjee. It is said that the provisional Parliament was number companypetent to pass the Act in 1951, because the companydition precedent for passing such a law had number been, as required by Art. 312, companyplied with.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Valid adaptation removed condition precedent of Council resolution, empowering provisional Parliament under Art. 379 to enact law regulating all-India services.

holdings.text: The Rules framed in 1955, therefore, cannot be challenged on the ground that the omitted words reappeared in Art. 312. The Rules derive their force from the Act and the form in which Art. 312 emerged [...] would not have any effect on the Rules. There is no force, therefore, in any of these three points, and we reject them.

anchor.surface_text: The further argument that the Rules were promulgated in 1955 when the words omitted by the Constitution Removal of Difficulties Order No. II had reappeared in Art. 312 and were, therefore, repugnant to Art. 312 inasmuch as there was numberresolution of the Council of States, as required by that Article, is, in our opinion, companypletely baseless.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules made under valid permanent Act of 1951; expiration of temporary adaptation order does not invalidate rules as they derive authority from Act, not Art. 312 directly.

holdings.text: We cannot read Art. 312 as laying down a mandate prohibiting Parliament from delegating authority to the Central Government to frame rules for the recruitment and the conditions of service of all-India services. We, therefore, reject this contention.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that in the circumstances of Art. 312 it companyld number have been the intention of the Constitution that the numerous and varied provisions that have to be made in order to regulate the recruitment and the companyditions of service of all-India services should all be enacted as statute law and numberhing should be delegated to the executive authorities.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Parliament may by law provide' does not prohibit delegation; regulation needs flexible rules changeable by executive; Delhi Laws Act permits delegation within limits.

holdings.text: reading s. 4 along with s. 3 of the Act it cannot be said [...] that there was excessive delegation to the Central Government by s. 3. We are, therefore, of opinion that the Act cannot be struck down on the ground of excessive delegation.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 which is important is in these terms- All rules in force immediately before the companymencement of this Act and applicable to an all-India service shall companytinue to be in force and shall be deemed to be rules made under this Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.4 adopts existing rules as policy and standard; s.3 requires state consultation and parliamentary laying/modification, ensuring legislative control per Delhi Laws Act.

holdings.text: the Punjab Government would have authority to institute the enquiry against him. [...] This contention must also be rejected.
holdings.reasoning_summary: R.5(1)-(8) procedure instituted by government under which officer serving (Punjab per r.2(b)); Central Govt enters post-enquiry for major penalties per r.5(9), r.4, Art.311(2).

holdings.text: This appeal by special leave raises the question of the constitutionality of the All-India Services Act, LXI of 1951 [...] [implicitly upheld as all challenges rejected].

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave raises the question of the companystitutionality of the All-India Services Act, LXI of 1951 hereinafter called the Act .

holdings.reasoning_summary: All six challenges to Act and Rules rejected; Act valid, delegation proper, proceedings properly instituted.

precedents.citation: Sankari Prasad Singh Deo v. Union of India and State of Bihar 1

anchor.surface_text: Reliance in this companynection is placed on Sankari Prasad Singh Deo v. Union of India and State of Bihar 1 , where dealing with an adaptation made in Art. 368, by the same order, this Court observed that the adaptation leaves the requirement of a special majority untouched . It is urged that if the President had made the adaptation in the way suggested by learned companynsel that would have left the requirement of a resolution supported by requisite majority untouched and would have been within the power of the President but inasmuch as the entire portion was omitted the President had exceeded his power.

precedents.case_name: Sankari Prasad Singh Deo v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: adaptation made in Art. 368 by the President under the same order left the requirement of a special majority untouched
precedents.cited_holding: the adaptation leaves the requirement of a special majority untouched

anchor.surface_text: It is enough to say that Sankari Prasad Singhs case 1 does number lay down that if the adaptation in Art. 368 had been made in some other manner it would have been invalid and unconstitutional. Reference to the fact that adaptation left the requirement of a special majority untouched was made obviously for the purpose of emphasising that there was numberreal ground of grievance and number for indicating that in the absence of the retention of that provision the adaptation would have been bad.

precedents.case_name: Sankari Prasad Singh Deo v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: does not lay down that adaptations in Art. 368 made in other manners would be invalid

anchor.surface_text: Now, it is well settled that it is companypetent for, the legislature to delegate to other authorities the power to frame rules to carry out the purposes of the law made by it was so held by the majority of Judges in Re The Delhi Laws Act, 1912 1 . The Delhi Laws case was, further examined in Rajnarain Singh The Chairman. Patna Administration Committee, Patna 2 , and the delegation was held to go to the extent of authorising an executive authority to modify the law made but number in any essential feature.

precedents.cited_proposition: legislature competent to delegate to other authorities the power to frame rules to carry out the purposes of the law made by it

precedents.citation: Rajnarain Singh The Chairman. Patna Administration Committee, Patna 2

anchor.surface_text: The Delhi Laws case was, further examined in Rajnarain Singh The Chairman. Patna Administration Committee, Patna 2 , and the delegation was held to go to the extent of authorising an executive authority to modify the law made but number in any essential feature. It was also observed that what companystitutes essential feature cannot be enunciated in general terms.

precedents.case_name: Rajnarain Singh v. Chairman, Patna Administration Committee
precedents.cited_proposition: delegation valid to extent of authorising executive to modify law but not in any essential feature; essential features cannot be enunciated in general terms

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection reference was made to the following observations of Mukherjea, J.  as he was then , in Re The Delhi Laws Act, 1912 1 at p. 982 The essential legislative function companysists in the determination or choosing of the legislative policy and of formally enacting that policy into a binding rule of companyduct. It is open to the legislature to formulate the policy as broadly and with as little or as much details as it thinks proper and it may delegate the rest of the legislative work to a subordinate authority who will work out the details within the framework of that policy.

precedents.cited_proposition: essential legislative function consists in determination of legislative policy and enacting it into binding rule of conduct; legislature may delegate filling details within policy framework
precedents.cited_holding: The essential legislative function companysists in the determination or choosing of the legislative policy and of formally enacting that policy into a binding rule of companyduct. ... So long as a policy is laid down and a standard established by statute numberconstitutional delegation of legislative power is involved...

anchor.surface_text: Re. 6. The last contention is that the Punjab Government has no authority to institute these proceedings under the Rules. It would be necessary in this connection to refer to the Rules. Rule 3 provides for penalties, which are seven in number. Rule 4 provides for the authorities, who can impose the penalties, and three of the penalties, namely, dismissal, removal or compulsory retirement, can only be imposed by the Central Government, while the other four penalties can be imposed by the State Government.

outcome.relief_summary: All six contentions of the appellant rejected. All-India Services Act, 1951 held constitutional. Delegation of rule-making power under s.3 valid, not excessive. Punjab Government held authorised to institute disciplinary enquiry under the Rules.
